title: 110_hr765
content: There is no information provided in the prev_chunk to assist with summarizing the curr_chunk. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles. Subsection (e) introduces the new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles. The credit amount for a new hybrid flexible fuel motor vehicle placed in service by the taxpayer is determined according to a specific table. The credit amount for a vehicle based on city fuel economy ranges from $1,500 to $3,500, depending on the percentage increase compared to a comparable vehicle. The city fuel economy for determining the credit of a new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle is based on E-85 ethanol gallon equivalent, while the comparable vehicle's fuel economy is based on gasoline gallon equivalent. The curr_chunk discusses the certification requirements for a flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle to qualify for a city fuel economy credit. It mentions the consultation with the Environmental Protection Agency and achieving a certain fuel economy threshold with E-85 ethanol. Additionally, it states that the subsection does not apply to vehicles eligible for a new qualified hybrid motor vehicle credit. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to the tax code regarding flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles. It includes changes to numeric limitations and conforming amendments to subsections. Amendments to the tax code regarding flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles include changes to numeric limitations and conforming amendments to subsections. Subsection (k) of section 30(B) is amended to exclude new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles from certain provisions, and subsection (b) of section 38 is amended to update references. The amendments made to the tax code regarding flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles include changes to numeric limitations and conforming amendments to subsections. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2006.
